noun.description: A word used to connect clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in the same clause (e.g. and, but, if).
The action or an instance of two or more events or things occurring at the same point in time or space.
examples: a conjunction of favorable political and economic circumstances
he postulated that the Americas were formed by the conjunction of floating islands

phrases: herbal medicine was used in conjunction with acupuncture and massage
As a complementary therapist, he works in conjunction with conventional animal doctors.
Several local hotels are offering deals in conjunction with the festival.
This section thus needs to be understood in conjunction with the chapter on process that follows.
They are designed to work in conjunction with a seat belt - not in place of it.
origin: Late Middle English: via Old French from Latin conjunctio(n-), from the verb conjungere (see conjoin).
